2:50 - isn't it easier here by using the logarithmic law of log(m/n)=log(m)-log(n)? In this case it would be B/10=log(I)-log(I₀), ⇒ log(I) = B/10+log(I₀). Then solve I.

An easy way to do the log without a calculator ( like on the mcat) for the problem at 1:10 is to say m+.n , where log( 4*10^7) so that 7+.4= 7.4. 7.4*10 is equal to 74, which is close to our initial value.
